content:
the arraignment for Nancy Ramirez a UCSB student accused of stealing two professors identities and using the information to alter her and other students grades has been postponed until May  because her lawyer was not in court PERIOD

James Kreyger the Santa Barbara County deputy district attorney prosecuting the case said Ramirez  is being charged with two felony counts of illegal access into a computer system and two felony counts of identity theft PERIOD The arraignment was postponed because Ramirezs privately retained attorney Nancy Dobrin failed to attend Fridays originally scheduled arraignment PERIOD Dobrin could not be reached for comment PERIOD Ramirez a native of Los Angeles is currently out of jail on  bail PERIOD

The UC Police Dept PERIOD arrested Ramirez on March  after she allegedly broke into the universitys computer grading system eGrades using the UCSBnetID and personal information of two professors PERIOD Police said Ramirez worked for the Goleta branch of the Allstate insurance company where she had access to the personal information of two UCSB professors who were insured by the firm PERIOD

Ramirez used the personal information of the professors to reset their UCSBnetID passwords police said PERIOD She is accused of changing her grade in one class from a B to an A as well as altering her roommates grades from an F to a B in one class and from a B to an A in another class PERIOD

In addition to county criminal trial proceedings Ramirez also awaits university disciplinary measures said Joseph Navarro associate dean of students for judicial affairs PERIOD He said the university is currently investigating the case PERIOD

Navarro said the Judicial Affairs Office might ask Ramirez to speak at a student conduct hearing PERIOD However her lawyer may advise her not to say anything at the university hearing because any statements she made could be used against her in any criminal proceedings PERIOD It is unclear what punishment Ramirez could face from the university PERIOD

We dont get computerrelated cases too often but based on prior cases and the seriousness of the breech her actions might warrant suspension or dismissal from UCSB Navarro said PERIOD

title: Court Delays Arraignment in Grade Falsification Case | The Daily Nexus
